snippet: The president’s tough rhetoric plays into Chinese economic nationalism.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump tweeted on May 5 that the China trade deal was off, the historical echoes in Beijing were loud and clear.  Almost exactly 100 years earlier, China’s “May Fourth Movement” of 1919 was a direct response to the actions of President Woodrow Wilson at the end of World War I. Wilson had promised China, an American ally, that German colonies in Shandong would be returned to Chinese sovereignty, but instead handed them to Japan. China exploded with anti-American, nationalist sentiment. One of the eventual consequences was the establishment of the Chinese Communist Party, which for the last 70 years has ruled the country.
